summary: This is a defense filing in the case of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, submitted by her attorneys from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman. It contains expert witness disclosures for Dr. Elizabeth Loftus and Dr. Park Dietz, who are expected to testify on memory science and forensic psychiatry to challenge the prosecution's theories of grooming and the reliability of witness memories. This document is a defense filing in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, dated November 1, 2021. It provides notice of expert witnesses the defense intends to call and outlines their expected testimony, which focuses on challenging the credibility of sexual assault allegations by discussing pathways to false allegations, memory issues, and mental health conditions. It also lists several expert witnesses in fields like forensic psychiatry, law, computer forensics, financial investigation, and document analysis.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the case. The document is a defense filing on her behalf, noting that a witness did not identify her as a perpetrator and reserving rights to rebut accuser testimony.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman law firm who is submitting this disclosure on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Elizabeth Loftus
persons.context: Cited for research on the implantation of false memories and how misinformation can alter event recollection, used by the defense to challenge the reliability of witness memories.

persons.name: Park Dietz
persons.context: Forensic psychiatrist disclosed as an expert who will testify to critique the concept of 'grooming,' discuss hindsight bias, the halo effect, and pathways to false allegations of sexual assault.

persons.name: Rocchio
persons.context: Referred to as 'Dr. Rocchio,' a government expert whose opinions on grooming and victim vulnerabilities are being critiqued by defense expert Dr. Dietz.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as a brilliant man with Cluster B personality traits who exploited the halo effect and manipulated people. His guilty plea is mentioned as an outcome that creates hindsight bias.

persons.name: Steve Bannon
persons.context: Mentioned in reference to a videotaped interview where Jeffrey Epstein discussed different kinds of power.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Cited by Epstein in an interview as an example of political power.

persons.name: Gerry Edelman
persons.context: Cited by Epstein in an interview as an example of intellectual power.

persons.name: Natalie Bennett
persons.context: Co-author of a cited academic paper on the construct of grooming in child sexual abuse.

persons.name: William O'Donohue
persons.context: Co-author of cited academic papers on grooming and pathways to false allegations of sexual assault.

persons.name: Jessica Engle
persons.context: Co-author of a cited academic paper on pathways to false allegations of sexual assault.

persons.name: Emily R. Dworkin
persons.context: Cited as an author of meta-analyses on mental disorders associated with sexual assault and PTSD following sexual assault.

persons.name: Caron Zlotnick
persons.context: Cited as a co-author of a study on chronicity in PTSD and predictors of its course.

persons.name: Meredith Warshaw
persons.context: Cited as a co-author with Caron Zlotnick on a study about PTSD.

persons.name: Ryan Hall
persons.context: Performed an independent medical and psychiatric evaluation of a witness (referred to as '2009'). He is expected to offer expert opinions and diagnoses, and testify that the witness did not identify Ghislaine Maxwell as a perpetrator.

persons.name: Bennett Gershman
persons.context: A Distinguished Professor of Law at Pace University and an expert on prosecutorial misconduct. Expected to testify on best practices to ensure prosecutorial integrity.

persons.name: Robert Kelso
persons.context: CEO of Forensic Pursuit. Expected to testify about user data, documents, photographs, and metadata from devices seized in the case, and to potentially rebut testimony from the government's expert Stephen Flatley.

persons.name: John Lopez
persons.context: Former IRS Special Agent. Expected to testify about his review of financial records and explain fund transfers relevant to the case.

persons.name: Gerald LaPorte
persons.role: Forensic Chemist and Document Dating Specialist, Defense Expert
persons.context: Expected to analyze documents for dates of creation, completeness, alteration, and manipulation.

persons.name: Jennifer Naso
persons.context: Expected to examine documents for authorship, authentication, and potential manipulation.

persons.name: Stephen Flatley
persons.context: Mentioned as a government expert whose testimony may be rebutted by defense expert Robert Kelso.

persons.name: Dr. Rocchio
persons.context: Mentioned as a government expert whose opinions the defense reserves the right to rebut.

connections.description: The document states the claim is that Maxwell recruited and groomed minors to provide sexualized massages for Epstein, which would amount to 'grooming-by-proxy'.
Pagliuca is submitting this expert disclosure on behalf of defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
Dr. Loftus is disclosed as an expert witness for the defense in Maxwell's case.
Dr. Dietz is disclosed as an expert witness for the defense in Maxwell's case.
Epstein gave a videotaped interview to Steve Bannon where he discussed power.
Epstein cited Clinton as an example of political power in an interview.
Dr. Hall evaluated a witness and is expected to testify that the witness did not identify Maxwell as a perpetrator.
Kelso is anticipated to testify in rebuttal to any testimony offered by the government's expert, Stephen Flatley.

events.title: Defense Expert Disclosure Filing
events.description: Defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell files expert witness disclosures for Dr. Elizabeth Loftus and Dr. Park Dietz.

events.title: Epstein's Guilty Plea
events.description: Referenced as a past event where Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to having sexual contact with post-pubescent minors, which is cited as creating hindsight bias.

locations: United States Attorney's Office Southern District of New York, New York, NY 10007
University of California, Irvine School of Law
University of Virginia School of Law
keyFacts: The defense plans to call memory expert Dr. Elizabeth Loftus to testify about false memories, suggestion, and how media coverage can contaminate memory.

The defense plans to call forensic psychiatrist Dr. Park Dietz to critique the prosecution's theory of 'grooming,' arguing it imputes motive without evidence and that 'grooming-by-proxy' has no scientific basis.

Dr. Dietz's testimony will address cognitive biases like hindsight bias (overestimating predictability after knowing an outcome) and the halo effect (where positive traits influence perception of unrelated characteristics), suggesting these affected perceptions of Epstein and Maxwell.
The document references a videotaped interview where Jeffrey Epstein discussed different kinds of power with Steve Bannon, mentioning Bill Clinton and Gerry Edelman.
Dr. Dietz cites academic literature proposing 11 pathways to false allegations of sexual assault, including lying, false memories, and personality disorders.

The defense filing outlines a strategy to challenge the credibility of sexual assault allegations by citing psychological research on false memories, intoxication, and personality disorders (Antisocial, Borderline, Histrionic) as potential pathways to false allegations.

The defense intends to call multiple expert witnesses, including a forensic psychiatrist (Ryan Hall) who found a witness did not identify Ghislaine Maxwell as a perpetrator, and a prosecutorial misconduct expert (Bennett Gershman).
Other defense experts include a computer forensics specialist (Robert Kelso), a financial investigator (John Lopez), and document examiners (Gerald LaPorte, Jennifer Naso) to analyze evidence.
The document references redacted witness names (e.g., 'witness 2009', journal pages by a redacted witness), indicating the use of pseudonyms or protective orders.
The defense reserves the right to rebut testimony from government experts like Dr. Rocchio and to call additional witnesses based on the government's case.
